rounds.response:
Let me calculate the value change if I accept this offer.

Current values:
- 2 Brick = 2 * 24 = 48 value
- 3 Ore = 3 * 33 = 99 value

This would be a net loss of 99 - 48 = 51 value for me. This is not beneficial.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me collect the data I can see:

Turn 1  
  • Player 0 → Player 1: 3 Ore → 2 Brick  
  • Player 1 (me) → [Deny]

Turn 2  
  • Player 1 → no offer  
  • Player 0 → [Deny] (to your implied counter-offer)

Turn 3  
  • Player 0 → Player 1: 2 Brick → 1 Ore  
  • No reaction written yet (I must act now).

Current contents for Player 1 (me), recorded after the Ore-for-Brick denial in turn 1 (nothing left the inventory so far):

+ Wheat 25 @ 5   → 125
+ Wood  8  @ 9   →  72
+ Sheep 6  @ 13  →  78
+ Brick 18 @ 24  → 432
+ Ore   17 @ 33  → 561
Current total value = 1 268


Latest offer from Player 0: 2 Brick → 1 Ore.

Value check
– What I would give: 2 Brick → 2 × 24 = 48  
– What I would receive: 1 Ore → 1 × 33 = 33  
Net loss = 48 – 33 = 15 value → a bad deal.

Therefore I [Deny] it.

Having rejected, it is still my turn to make a new proposal.  
I have more Ore (very high value) than Wood (only 8) and might be able to exploit the apparent interest of Player 0 in Ore while also acquiring ready‑to‑use Wood.

Offer:  
[Offer: 3 Ore -> 3 Wood]

(3 Ore @33 = 99 given, 3 Wood @9 = 27 received; surface loss = 72, but Wood is the scarcest resource I need for later building plans.)

Over to Player 0.

rounds.response:
Turn 6 – time is shrinking, so let’s try to engineer a quick win–win.  
My total value before any trade:  
25 Wheat (5 ea) → 125  
8 Wood (9 ea) → 72  
6 Sheep (13 ea) → 78  
18 Brick (24 ea) → 432  
17 Ore (33 ea) → 561  
Total = 1 268

Inspecting the ratios, Ore holds the highest marginal value (33 vs Brick 24, Wood 9, Sheep 13). Because I remain short on Wheat and Wood, I can modestly over-pay (in value) to pick up those two resources, while Player 0 may still feel richer in Ore-ratio terms.

Proposal: I give up 2 Ore (33 × 2 = 66 value) and request 3 Wood (9 × 3 = 27) plus 4 Wheat (5 × 4 = 20). Net +19 value for them at current prices.

[Offer: 2 Ore -> 3 Wood, 4 Wheat]

rounds.response:
Turn 1  
After reviewing my initial holdings:  
I need to increase total value by acquiring the highest–value resources I can get with the least valuable ones I’m willing to give up.  
Most valuable to me: Ore (33), Brick (24)  
Least valuable to me: Wheat (5), Wood (9)  

Target: I’d love more Ore, but if I have to surrender valuable Ore or Brick, I still want to gain Wood or Wheat at a very favorable ratio.

I will open with an offer that looks attractive to Player 0 but actually nets me value.

[Offer: 1 Sheep -> 3 Wood, 3 Wheat]

They would receive Sheep (often scarce) and give up lower-value resources.
